testTitle: Life in the UK Test - Norman Conquest & Medieval Period
testDescription: Comprehensive test covering the Norman Conquest of 1066, medieval England, feudal system, and key developments in law, culture, and society.

questions.stem: In which year did the Norman Conquest take place?
questions.explanation: The Norman Conquest took place in 1066 when William of Normandy defeated Harold Godwinson at the Battle of Hastings.

questions.stem: Who was William the Conqueror?
questions.explanation: William the Conqueror was the Duke of Normandy who claimed the English throne and defeated Harold at Hastings.

questions.stem: The Battle of Hastings was fought between which armies?
questions.explanation: The Battle of Hastings was fought between William's Norman army and Harold Godwinson's Anglo-Saxon forces.

questions.stem: Harold Godwinson died at the Battle of Hastings.
questions.explanation: True. Harold Godwinson, the last Anglo-Saxon king, was killed at the Battle of Hastings, ending Anglo-Saxon rule.

questions.stem: What was the Domesday Book?

options.label: A survey of England's lands and people

questions.explanation: The Domesday Book was a comprehensive survey ordered by William I in 1086 to record land ownership and resources for taxation.

questions.stem: The Norman Conquest brought which changes to England?
questions.explanation: Normans brought new architecture, French language influence, and the feudal system. Protestantism came much later in the 16th century.

questions.stem: What was the feudal system?

options.label: A system where land was held in exchange for service

questions.explanation: The feudal system was a way of organizing society where land was held in exchange for military or other services.

questions.stem: Who was at the top of the feudal system?
questions.explanation: The King was at the top of the feudal system, owning all land and granting it to nobles in exchange for loyalty and service.

questions.stem: The Bayeux Tapestry depicts the Norman Conquest.
questions.explanation: True. The Bayeux Tapestry is a famous embroidered cloth that tells the story of the Norman Conquest.

questions.stem: What language did the Norman nobles speak?
questions.explanation: Norman nobles spoke Norman French, which became the language of the court and government for several centuries.

questions.stem: Which famous buildings were built by the Normans?
questions.explanation: Normans built the Tower of London, Durham Cathedral, and rebuilt Westminster Abbey. St Paul's was built much later by Christopher Wren.

questions.stem: What was a castle's keep?
questions.explanation: The keep was the central, strongest part of a castle where the lord lived and which served as the last line of defense.

questions.stem: Henry II established a system of common law.
questions.explanation: True. Henry II (1154-1189) established a system of common law that applied throughout England, replacing local customs.

questions.stem: Who was Thomas Becket?
questions.explanation: Thomas Becket was Archbishop of Canterbury who was murdered in 1170 after a dispute with King Henry II.

questions.stem: What was the Magna Carta?

options.label: A document limiting the king's power

questions.explanation: The Magna Carta (1215) was a charter that limited the power of King John and established that even the king was subject to the law.

questions.stem: King John was forced to sign the Magna Carta in 1215.
questions.explanation: True. King John was forced to sign the Magna Carta by his barons at Runnymede in 1215.

questions.stem: What did the Magna Carta establish?

options.label: No one is above the law

questions.explanation: Magna Carta established rule of law, fair trial rights, and taxation limits. Universal voting came much later in history.

questions.stem: Which king was known as the 'Lionheart'?
questions.explanation: Richard I (1189-1199) was known as 'the Lionheart' for his role in the Third Crusade.

questions.stem: The Crusades were religious wars fought in the Holy Land.
questions.explanation: True. The Crusades were a series of religious wars fought between Christians and Muslims for control of the Holy Land.

questions.stem: What was a medieval guild?

options.label: An association of craftsmen or merchants

questions.explanation: A guild was an association of craftsmen or merchants who controlled their trade and maintained standards in medieval towns.

questions.stem: Medieval society was divided into which main groups?
questions.explanation: Medieval society was traditionally divided into three estates: nobles (fighters), clergy (prayers), and peasants (workers). Merchants emerged later.

questions.stem: What was the Black Death?
questions.explanation: The Black Death was a devastating plague that swept through Europe in the 14th century, killing about one-third of the population.

questions.stem: The Black Death arrived in Britain in 1348.
questions.explanation: True. The Black Death reached Britain in 1348 and caused massive social and economic changes.

questions.stem: What was the result of the Black Death in England?
questions.explanation: The Black Death caused labor shortages, leading to higher wages, social changes, and unrest. Population decreased dramatically.
